title: Quiz 3: NCK Paper One - July 2009
description: Licensure Examination covering General Nursing, Pediatrics, and Medical-Surgical Nursing (July 2009).

questions.question: The Abdominal Aorta divides at the level of the 4th Lumbar vertebra into which arteries?
questions.explanation: The abdominal aorta terminates by bifurcating into the left and right Common Iliac Arteries at the level of the L4 vertebra. These subsequently divide into internal and external iliacs.
questions.hint: It splits into two main branches named 'common' before splitting further.

questions.question: Which of the following groups represents ORGANIC causes of a child's failure to thrive?

options.text: Lack of active feeding, cleft palate, HIV infection

questions.explanation: Failure to thrive is classified as Organic (medical/physical causes) or Non-organic (psychosocial/environmental). Option B contains only medical conditions. Options A, C, and D contain non-organic factors like 'lack of active feeding', 'emotional deprivation', and 'poor nutrition'.
questions.hint: Look for the option that lists ONLY medical diseases or physical defects, with no environmental factors.

questions.question: An indirect bilirubin level of 2.0 mg/dl (34 mol) typically indicates:
questions.explanation: Indirect (unconjugated) bilirubin is a byproduct of heme breakdown. Elevated levels usually indicate excessive destruction of red blood cells (hemolysis) which overwhelms the liver's conjugation capacity.
questions.hint: This substance comes from the breakdown of RBCs.

questions.question: The standard adult dose of Nitrofurantoin for UTIs is:
questions.explanation: The classic dosing for immediate-release Nitrofurantoin is 50-100 mg QID (four times daily). Sustained release formulations (Macrodantin) may be dosed BID.
questions.hint: It is typically taken with meals, four times a day.

questions.question: When inserting a naso-gastric tube, asking the patient to swallow helps because:

options.text: The epiglottis closes the trachea and directs the tube to the oesophagus
The tube does not get entangled in the naso-pharynx

questions.explanation: Swallowing triggers the laryngeal elevation and epiglottic closure, blocking the airway and opening the esophageal sphincter, allowing the tube to pass into the GI tract rather than the lungs.
questions.hint: Think about the anatomy of the throat and protection of the airway.

questions.question: What is the appropriate nursing intervention for a patient with 'ineffective airway clearance related to weak cough'?

options.text: Help the patient to sit up-right
Teach the patient how to cough effectively

questions.explanation: For a 'weak cough', the priority is to improve the cough mechanism itself through teaching techniques like splinting or huff coughing. Suctioning is a secondary measure if the patient cannot clear secretions independently.
questions.hint: Address the specific problem ('weak cough') with a skill-based intervention.

questions.question: Which finding suggests Facial Palsy (Bell's Palsy)?

options.text: Loss of taste, insidious onset of paralysis
Sudden onset of paralysis on one side, pain behind the ear
Headache, sounds seem louder on the un-affected side

questions.explanation: Bell's Palsy presents with sudden unilateral facial weakness. Pain behind the ear (mastoid) often precedes it. Hyperacusis (sounds seeming louder) occurs on the AFFECTED side, not the unaffected side.
questions.hint: Onset is usually rapid, not insidious.

questions.question: Before palpating the abdomen, the nurse should first:

options.text: Ask the patient to point to any painful areas
Depress the abdomen using the palmer surface of fingers

questions.explanation: The nurse must identify painful areas first to examine them LAST. Palpating a painful area first causes muscle guarding, which interferes with the rest of the examination.
questions.hint: You want to avoid causing pain at the beginning of the exam.

questions.question: Which group of surgical sutures are digested and absorbed by the body?
questions.explanation: Absorbable sutures include Catgut (natural), Vicryl (synthetic), and Dexon (synthetic). Silk, Nylon (polyamide), and Prolene (polypropylene) are non-absorbable.
questions.hint: Silk and Nylon are permanent/non-absorbable.

questions.question: In breast cancer management, systemic chemotherapy is most strongly indicated for:

options.text: Only post-menopausal women with nodal involvement
Pre-menopausal women even without nodal involvement
All patients with evidence of nodal involvement

questions.explanation: Systemic chemotherapy is standard for node-positive breast cancer to treat micrometastases and reduce recurrence risk, regardless of menopausal status.
questions.hint: Spread to the lymph nodes implies the disease is systemic.

questions.question: The humoral immune response is characterized by:

options.text: Release of cytokines for destruction of antigens

questions.explanation: Humoral immunity is mediated by B-cells transforming into plasma cells to produce antibodies (immunoglobulins). Cell-mediated immunity involves T-cells and cytokines.
questions.hint: 'Humor' refers to body fluids, where antibodies circulate.

questions.question: The most important health message for a client with Urticaria is:

options.text: Avoid contact with the causative agent/allergen
Expose the affected area to sunshine

questions.explanation: Urticaria (hives) is an allergic reaction. The most effective long-term management is identifying and avoiding the trigger. Benzene hexachloride is for lice/scabies.
questions.hint: Prevention is better than cure.

questions.question: Signs of Acute Thyroid Storm after subtotal thyroidectomy include:
questions.explanation: Thyroid storm is a hypermetabolic crisis characterized by high fever (hyperthermia), extreme tachycardia, and cardiovascular collapse (hypotension).
questions.hint: Everything speeds up dangerously - heat, heart rate, metabolism.

questions.question: Which of the following are INTRINSIC causes of airway obstruction requiring tracheostomy?

options.text: Cancer of thyroid gland, Ludwigâ€™s angina
Multiple laryngeal papilloma, tracheal trauma, pharyngeal cancer

questions.explanation: Intrinsic causes physically block the lumen from the inside (tumors, trauma/stenosis). Thyroid cancer and Ludwig's angina cause EXTRINSIC compression. Head injuries cause functional failure.
questions.hint: Look for conditions that grow inside the airway or damage the airway structure directly.

questions.question: According to IMCI, an infant (2 months) with Very Severe Pneumonia will manifest with:

options.text: Difficulty in breathing, inability to breast feed

questions.explanation: Inability to drink or breastfeed is a general danger sign that classifies pneumonia as 'Very Severe Disease'. Fast breathing alone is 'Pneumonia'. Chest indrawing is 'Severe Pneumonia'.
questions.hint: Look for the general danger sign that indicates the child is critically ill.

questions.question: What is the IV Ringer's Lactate protocol for a 1-year-old infant with severe dehydration (Plan C)?

options.text: 50 mls/kg in 1 hour, then 50 mls/kg in 5 hours
20 mls/kg bolus, then 80 mls/kg in 6 hours
30 mls/kg bolus, then 70 mls/kg in 6 hours
30 mls/kg in 1st hour, then 70 mls/kg in 5 hours

richContent.content:
AgeFirst 30ml/kgNext 70ml/kg
Infant (< 12 mo)1 hour5 hours
Child (12 mo - 5 yr)30 mins2.5 hours

questions.explanation: The standard protocol for infants (< 12 months) is 30ml/kg over 1 hour, followed by 70ml/kg over 5 hours (Total 6 hours). Note: A '1 year old' is technically a child (3 hour protocol), but exams often categorize '1 year old infant' under the infant protocol. Option D is the only valid IMCI schedule listed.
questions.hint: Infants need slower rehydration (6 hours total) compared to older children.

questions.question: A complication of posterior dislocation of the hip is:
questions.explanation: The sciatic nerve runs posterior to the hip joint. A posterior dislocation (femoral head pushed back) can stretch, compress, or shear this nerve.
questions.hint: Which major nerve runs behind the hip joint?

questions.question: Laboratory results of a patient with massive thermal burns in the acute phase will reveal:
questions.explanation: Massive burns cause Hypocalcemia (calcium trapped in necrotic tissue/lost with albumin), Hyperkalemia (cell lysis), Hyponatremia (fluid shift), and Myoglobinuria (increased myoglobin).
questions.hint: Electrolyte imbalances include high potassium and low sodium/calcium.

questions.question: Bacterial acid in dental plaque facilitates deposition of minerals on the tooth thereby causing dental caries.
questions.explanation: Bacterial acid causes DEMINERALIZATION (loss of minerals), not deposition. This loss of minerals weakens the enamel and causes caries.
questions.hint: Does acid add minerals or dissolve them?

questions.question: One of the causative factors for dental caries is highly refined carbohydrates.
questions.explanation: Refined carbohydrates (sugars) provide the substrate for bacteria to produce the acid that erodes tooth enamel.
questions.hint: Think about what foods dentists tell you to avoid.

questions.question: Match the eye symptom with the likely condition:

pairs.left: Occasional headaches, frequent change of glasses
Severe unilateral headaches, diminution of vision

questions.explanation: Refractive errors cause eye strain and need for prescription updates. Acute glaucoma causes sudden severe pressure pain and vision loss.
questions.hint: One is a chronic vision correction issue; the other is an acute medical emergency.
